Electrochemical CO production from CO2 electrolysis has been considered the most economically viable approach among various candidate products. AuCu bimetallic alloys are currently receiving attent...
meta.name: twitter:description

meta.content: Electrochemical CO production from CO2 electrolysis has been considered the most economically viable approach among various candidate products. AuCu bimetallic alloys are currently receiving attention for their potential to tailor catalytic activity. Here, we synthesized a dilute AuCu alloy nanostructure with an AuCu atomic composition ratio of 3% by using a simple electrochemical treatment method on a 200 nm-thick Au thin film. The dilute AuCu alloy catalyst shows an exceptional CO2 reduction activity in terms of selectivity and overpotential for CO production. In addition, the stability property is more significantly enhanced as compared to pure Au nanostructures. In addition, we describe an in situ tailoring method of catalytic activity for Au nanostructures by repeating an electrochemical treatment process that is performed for forming the Au nanostructure. This approach will be a promising and facile strategy not only for reactive Au catalysts but also to increase the stability activity simultaneously by utilizing Cu impurities existing in an aqueous electrolyte for CO2 reduction.
meta.name: citation_abstract

head.title: Facile electrochemical synthesis of dilute AuCu alloy nanostructures for selective and long-term stable CO2 electrolysis: The Journal of Chemical Physics: Vol 153, No 5

ul.li:
Facile electrochemical synthesis of dilute AuCu alloy nanostructures for selective and long-term stable CO
2
electrolysis

div.div:
Electrochemical CO production from CO
2
electrolysis has been considered the most economically viable approach among various candidate products. AuCu bimetallic alloys are currently receiving attention for their potential to tailor catalytic activity. Here, we synthesized a dilute AuCu alloy nanostructure with an AuCu atomic composition ratio of 3% by using a simple electrochemical treatment method on a 200 nm-thick Au thin film. The dilute AuCu alloy catalyst shows an exceptional CO
2
reduction activity in terms of selectivity and overpotential for CO production. In addition, the stability property is more significantly enhanced as compared to pure Au nanostructures. In addition, we describe an
in situ
tailoring method of catalytic activity for Au nanostructures by repeating an electrochemical treatment process that is performed for forming the Au nanostructure. This approach will be a promising and facile strategy not only for reactive Au catalysts but also to increase the stability activity simultaneously by utilizing Cu impurities existing in an aqueous electrolyte for CO
2
reduction.
I. INTRODUCTION
Section:

Electrochemical CO
2
reduction reaction (CO
2
RR) to synthesize fuels and chemical feedstocks is a promising technology for storing renewable energy while reducing greenhouse gas emissions.
1â4
1. S. Garg, M. Li, A. Z. Weber, L. Ge, L. Li, V. Rudolph, G. Wang, and T. E. Rufford, J. Mater. Chem. A
8
, 1511â
1544
(2020).
https://doi.org/10.1039/c9ta13298h
2. M. G. Kibria, J. P. Edwards, C. M. Gabardo, C. T. Dinh, A. Seifitokaldani, D. Sinton, and E. H. Sargent, Adv. Mater.
31
, 1807166 (2019).
https://doi.org/10.1002/adma.201807166
3. J. T. Song, H. Song, B. Kim, and J. Oh, Catalysts
9
, 224 (2019).
https://doi.org/10.3390/catal9030224
4. S. Nitopi, E. Bertheussen, S. B. Scott, X. Liu, A. K. Engstfeld, S. Horch, B. Seger, I. E. L. Stephens, K. Chan, C. Hahn, J. K. NÃ¸rskov, T. F. Jaramillo, and I. Chorkendorff, Chem. Rev.
119
, 7610â
7672
(2019).
https://doi.org/10.1021/acs.chemrev.8b00705
According to a recent techno-economic analysis, selective and efficient CO production from CO
2
electrolysis can be economically viable due to the high CO market price and large market size.
5â7
5. M. Jouny, W. Luc, and F. Jiao, Ind. Eng. Chem. Res.
57
, 2165â
2177
(2018).
https://doi.org/10.1021/acs.iecr.7b03514
6. O. S. Bushuyev, P. De Luna, C. T. Dinh, L. Tao, G. Saur, J. van de Lagemaat, S. O. Kelley, and E. H. Sargent, Joule
2
, 825â
832
(2018).
https://doi.org/10.1016/j.joule.2017.09.003
7. S. Verma, B. Kim, H.-R. M. Jhong, S. Ma, and P. J. A. Kenis, ChemSusChem
9
, 1972â
1979
(2016).
https://doi.org/10.1002/cssc.201600394
Noble metals, such as Au and Ag, are well-known electrocatalysts for CO
2
RR to CO, and various approaches, such as nanostructuring, surface functionalization, and alloying, have been suggested to promote CO
2
RR activity of noble metal catalysts toward high selectivity and energy efficiency.
8â14
8. J. T. Song, H. Ryoo, M. Cho, J. Kim, J.-G. Kim, S.-Y. Chung, and J. Oh, Adv. Energy Mater.
7
, 1601103 (2017).
https://doi.org/10.1002/aenm.201601103
9. J. Kim, J. T. Song, H. Ryoo, J.-G. Kim, S.-Y. Chung, and J. Oh, J. Mater. Chem. A
6
, 5119â
5128
(2018).
https://doi.org/10.1039/c8ta01010b
10. M. Cho, J. T. Song, S. Back, Y. Jung, and J. Oh, ACS Catal.
8
, 1178â
1185
(2018).
https://doi.org/10.1021/acscatal.7b03449
11. Z. Gu, H. Shen, L. Shang, X. Lv, L. Qian, and G. Zheng, Small Methods
2
, 1800121 (2018).
https://doi.org/10.1002/smtd.201800121
12. J. Tamura, A. Ono, Y. Sugano, C. Huang, H. Nishizawa, and S. Mikoshiba, Phys. Chem. Chem. Phys.
17
, 26072â
26078
(2015).
https://doi.org/10.1039/c5cp03028e
13. C. Kim, T. Eom, M. S. Jee, H. Jung, H. Kim, B. K. Min, and Y. J. Hwang, ACS Catal.
7
, 779â
785
(2017).
https://doi.org/10.1021/acscatal.6b01862
14. J. He, N. J. J. Johnson, A. Huang, and C. P. Berlinguette, ChemSusChem
11
, 48â
57
(2018).
https://doi.org/10.1002/cssc.201701825
Recently, alloys of noble metals have received much attention as they can reduce high material costs and tune catalytic properties by tailoring the surface binding strength of intermediate species.
15â20
15. K. Liu, M. Ma, L. Wu, M. Valenti, D. Cardenas-Morcoso, J. P. Hofmann, J. Bisquert, S. Gimenez, and W. A. Smith, ACS Appl. Mater. Interfaces
11
, 16546â
16555
(2019).
https://doi.org/10.1021/acsami.9b01553
16. D. Kim, J. Resasco, Y. Yu, A. M. Asiri, and P. Yang, Nat. Commun.
5
, 4948 (2014).
https://doi.org/10.1038/ncomms5948
17. D. Kim, C. Xie, N. Becknell, Y. Yu, M. Karamad, K. Chan, E. J. Crumlin, J. K. NÃ¸rskov, and P. Yang, J. Am. Chem. Soc.
139
, 8329â
8336
(2017).
https://doi.org/10.1021/jacs.7b03516
18. S. Zhao, R. Jin, and R. Jin, ACS Energy Lett.
3
, 452â
462
(2018).
https://doi.org/10.1021/acsenergylett.7b01104
19. Y. Feng, Z. Li, H. Liu, C. Dong, J. Wang, S. A. Kulinich, and X. Du, Langmuir
34
, 13544â
13549
(2018).
https://doi.org/10.1021/acs.langmuir.8b02837
20. M. Ma, H. A. Hansen, M. Valenti, Z. Wang, A. Cao, M. Dong, and W. A. Smith, Nano Energy
42
, 51â
57
(2017).
https://doi.org/10.1016/j.nanoen.2017.09.043
In particular, AuCu bimetallic alloy materials have been focused on their exceptional CO
2
RR catalytic activity.
21â23
21. E. Andrews, Y. Fang, and J. Flake, J. Appl. Electrochem.
48
, 435â
441
(2018).
https://doi.org/10.1007/s10800-018-1166-6
22. Z. Chang, S. Huo, W. Zhang, J. Fang, and H. Wang, J. Phys. Chem. C
121
, 11368â
11379
(2017).
https://doi.org/10.1021/acs.jpcc.7b01586
23. M. B. Ross, C. T. Dinh, Y. Li, D. Kim, P. De Luna, E. H. Sargent, and P. Yang, J. Am. Chem. Soc.
139
, 9359â
9363
(2017).
https://doi.org/10.1021/jacs.7b04892
For instance, Liu
et al.
investigated the correlation of catalytic activity and electronic structures for AuCu alloy thin films.
15
15. K. Liu, M. Ma, L. Wu, M. Valenti, D. Cardenas-Morcoso, J. P. Hofmann, J. Bisquert, S. Gimenez, and W. A. Smith, ACS Appl. Mater. Interfaces
11
, 16546â
16555
(2019).
https://doi.org/10.1021/acsami.9b01553
They found that the increasing Au ratio can cause a shift of the d-band center, resulting in low CO coverage from the decreased
*
CO binding strength on the surface. That is, CO formation is further promoted with higher Au content in AuCu alloy. It was also reported that self-assembled AuCu bimetallic nanoparticles induce a synergetic effect from electronic and geometric structures such that Au
3
Cu shows the highest CO Faradaic efficiency (FE) of â¼60%.
16
16. D. Kim, J. Resasco, Y. Yu, A. M. Asiri, and P. Yang, Nat. Commun.
5
, 4948 (2014).
https://doi.org/10.1038/ncomms5948

Nanostructuring of metal alloy materials could further improve the catalyst performance.
24,25
24. W. Zhu, L. Zhang, P. Yang, C. Hu, H. Dong, Z.-J. Zhao, R. Mu, and J. Gong, ACS Energy Lett.
3
, 2144â
2149
(2018).
https://doi.org/10.1021/acsenergylett.8b01286
25. K. Sun, T. Cheng, L. Wu, Y. Hu, J. Zhou, A. Maclennan, Z. Jiang, Y. Gao, W. A. Goddard, and Z. Wang, J. Am. Chem. Soc.
139
, 15608â
15611
(2017).
https://doi.org/10.1021/jacs.7b09251
For instance, Zhu
et al.
fabricated a dealloyed, nanoporous Au
3
Cu catalyst showing over 90% CO FE at â0.38 V vs reversible hydrogen electrode (RHE).
24
24. W. Zhu, L. Zhang, P. Yang, C. Hu, H. Dong, Z.-J. Zhao, R. Mu, and J. Gong, ACS Energy Lett.
3
, 2144â
2149
(2018).
https://doi.org/10.1021/acsenergylett.8b01286
Similarly, AuâFe coreâshell nanoparticles, synthesized by leaching out of the surface Fe atom using a solvothermal method, exhibit a CO selectivity of 97.6% at â0.4 V vs RHE and long-term stability for 90 h.
25
25. K. Sun, T. Cheng, L. Wu, Y. Hu, J. Zhou, A. Maclennan, Z. Jiang, Y. Gao, W. A. Goddard, and Z. Wang, J. Am. Chem. Soc.
139
, 15608â
15611
(2017).
https://doi.org/10.1021/jacs.7b09251

Herein, we describe a facile electrochemical approach to synthesize nanostructured AuCu alloy thin films for efficient and selective CO
2
RR. Previously, we demonstrated that sequential electrochemical anodization and reduction steps, called the reduced anodic (RA) treatment, on 200 nm-thick Au thin films formed nanostructured Au thin films with controlled morphology and achieved outstanding CO
2
RR activity for CO production. In this work, to alloy Au with Cu by using this electrochemical treatment, Cu was deposited on the Au surface prior to the RA treatment. Depending on the amounts of Cu deposition, this electrochemical process forms AuCu alloy nanostructures with a controlled AuCu ratio. Interestingly, these AuCu alloy nanostructures show comparable CO
2
RR activity to pure Au nanostructures but with dramatically improved stability due to the presence of a small quantity of alloying Cu. Finally, based on the result for the dilute AuCu alloy, we also present
in situ
surface modification in which a small amount of Cu is deposited and thereby alloyed with Au nanostructures by repetition of the RA treatment, allowing not only to re-activate the CO selectivity of Au catalysts but also to extend the lifespan of the catalysts during CO
2
electrolysis.
II. RESULTS AND DISCUSSION
Section:

Figure 1(a)
is the schematic illustration of a three-step electrochemical process, modified from our previous research,
8,9
8. J. T. Song, H. Ryoo, M. Cho, J. Kim, J.-G. Kim, S.-Y. Chung, and J. Oh, Adv. Energy Mater.
7
, 1601103 (2017).
https://doi.org/10.1002/aenm.201601103
9. J. Kim, J. T. Song, H. Ryoo, J.-G. Kim, S.-Y. Chung, and J. Oh, J. Mater. Chem. A
6
, 5119â
5128
(2018).
https://doi.org/10.1039/c8ta01010b
to fabricate nanoporous AuCu alloy thin films. In this process, nanoporous AuCu alloy thin films were formed by the electrochemical reduction of the AuCu hydroxide films, which were produced by anodization of Cu islands on Au thin films (hereafter, Cu/Au thin films). The Cu islands (or even continuous layers) on Au thin films can be formed by various deposition techniques, but in this work, we used electrochemical deposition (ED) of Cu on Au thin films.
Figures 1(b)â1(e)
are the scanning electron microscopy (SEM) images corresponding to the representative steps in the electrochemical treatment. After electrodeposition of Cu in a mixed solution of 50 mM CuSO
4
and 50 mM H
2
SO
4
for 10 s, Cu islands with thicknesses of a few hundred nanometers were formed on an e-beam-deposited, 200 nm-thick Au thin film on a Si substrate [
Figs. 1(b)
and
1(c)
]. Energy dispersive spectroscopy (EDS) also revealed that the electroplated Cu grew as islands on an Au film (see Fig. S1 of the
supplementary material
). Then, the Cu/Au thin films were anodized by potentiostatic polarization at 2.50 V (vs RHE, all given potential is hereafter expressed as RHE unless otherwise noted) for 40 min in a 0.2 M KHCO
3
solution (pH 8.4). As a result of anodization, â¼400 nm-thick, sponge-like nanoporous anodic films were formed on the Au film [
Fig. 1(d)
]. X-ray photoelectron spectroscopy (XPS) indicates that the nanoporous anodic films are AuCu hydroxide as strong peaks of ionic Au
3+
and Cu
2+
are observed along with the large signal of oxygen in the O1s binding energy responsible for metal hydroxide (see Fig. S2 of the
supplementary material
).
26â28
26. M. Peuckert, F. P. Coenen, and H. P. Bonzel, Surf. Sci.
141
, 515â
532
(1984).
https://doi.org/10.1016/0039-6028(84)90146-8
27. M. C. Biesinger, L. W. M. Lau, A. R. Gerson, and R. S. C. Smart, Appl. Surf. Sci.
257
, 887â
898
(2010).
https://doi.org/10.1016/j.apsusc.2010.07.086
28. J.-C. Dupin, D. Gonbeau, P. Vinatier, and A. Levasseur, Phys. Chem. Chem. Phys.
2
, 1319â
1324
(2000).
https://doi.org/10.1039/a908800h
Briefly, as shown in Fig. S2 of the
supplementary material
, two strong peaks of ionic Au
3+
are found at â¼86.3 eV and â¼90.1 eV in the Au4f spectrum, and two strong satellite peaks, which are associated with the presence of Cu(OH)
2
or CuO, are simultaneously observed at around 942 eV and 962 eV in the Cu2p spectrum. Because the shape of the satellite peak can assist in the determination of chemical state, a broad and singlet-like peak shape found at around 942 eV in the Cu2p spectrum is indicative of that the resultant structure contains Cu(OH)
2
rather than CuO.
27
27. M. C. Biesinger, L. W. M. Lau, A. R. Gerson, and R. S. C. Smart, Appl. Surf. Sci.
257
, 887â
898
(2010).
https://doi.org/10.1016/j.apsusc.2010.07.086
Furthermore, it should be noted that the binding energy for ionic Au
3+
of pure Au(OH)
3
is generally located at 85.9 eV and 89.7 eV, respectively. However, for the nanoporous anodic films, there happens a positive shift of the Au
3+
peaks by â¼0.40 eV. This binding energy shift can occur during the change in electron density around the base element (i.e., in this case of Au
3+
), suggesting that the ionic Au
3+
is not existing alone but having interaction with Cu
2+
. In addition to the large signal of presence of oxygen, therefore, the XPS analysis has confirmed that the nanoporous anodic films are AuCu hydroxide as the result of anodization of the Cu/Au film. Finally, galvanostatic electrochemical reduction at a current density of â0.5 mA cm
â2
was applied to the nanoporous, and AuCu hydroxide layers and porous AuCu alloy nanostructures with a height of 220 nm were formed on the remaining Au thin film/Si substrate [
Fig. 1(e)
]. Hereafter, we dub the nanoporous AuCu alloy by the modified RA treatment as RA-AuCu. We note that similar AuCu alloy nanostructures are formed by the modified RA treatment on various Cu morphologies on Au films (see Fig. S3 of the
supplementary material
).

FIG. 1.
(a) Schematic illustration of morphology evolution of porous AuCu alloy nanostructures during modified reduced anodic (RA) treatment. [(b)â(d)] Scanning electron microscopy (SEM) images corresponding to an illustration shown in (a). (b) Au thin film deposited on a Si substrate with Ti as an adhesion layer. (c) Atypically shaped, Cu islands with thicknesses of a few hundred nanometers formed on the Au thin film (Cu/Au thin film). Randomly distributed Cu islands were deposited on the Au thin film by potentiostatic electrodeposition at â0.10 V [vs Ag/AgCl (in 3 M NaCl)] for 10 s in a mixed solution of 50 mM CuSO
4
and 50 mM H
2
SO
4
. (d) Nanoporous AuCu hydroxide layers obtained by potentiostatic anodization of the prepared Cu/Au thin film at 2.50 V for 40 min in a 0.2 M KHCO
3
solution. (e) Porous AuCu alloy nanostructures formed after subsequent galvanostatic reduction with a relatively low reduction current density (e.g., â0.5 mA cm
â2
). Insets in (b)â(d) are the corresponding plan-view SEM images.

To identify the surface and chemical states of RA-AuCu, XPS study was carried out.
Figure 2
shows the XPS profiles of nanoporous Au formed by the RA treatment with or without Cu, that is, RA-AuCu and RA-Au. Note that the XPS profile for a bare Au film is included for comparison. As shown in
Fig. 2(a)
, the binding energy for Au4f
7/2
of RA-Au is 84.04 eV, which is consistent with that of a bare Au film, whereas RA-AuCu positively shifts the Au4f
7/2
peak by â¼0.30 eV. This blue shift in Au4f binding energy is mainly due to depletion of d charge of Au upon Cu introduction in Au lattices. Briefly, according to the charge compensation model, the loss of d charge at the Au site leads to an effective Coulombic potential for the remaining electrons, thereby causing a positive 4f binding energy shift.
29â31
29. R. E. Watson, J. Hudis, and M. L. Perlman, Phys. Rev. B
4
, 4139â
4144
(1971).
https://doi.org/10.1103/physrevb.4.4139
30. W. Eberhardt, S. C. Wu, R. Garrett, D. Sondericker, and F. Jona, Phys. Rev. B
31
, 8285â
8287
(1985).
https://doi.org/10.1103/physrevb.31.8285
31. M. Kuhn and T. K. Sham, Phys. Rev. B
49
, 1647â
1661
(1994).
https://doi.org/10.1103/physrevb.49.1647
The incorporation of Cu into Au sites is also clearly visible in the Cu2p spectra in
Fig. 2(b)
. Obviously, there are two distinct peaks of Cu2p
1/2
at â¼952.0 eV and Cu2p
3/2
at â¼932.2 eV, respectively, while any peaks relating to Cu existence are not observed in RA-Au. Since the binding energy for Cu2p
3/2
of pure Cu is generally known as â¼932.5 eV [see Fig. S2(b) of the
supplementary material
],
31
31. M. Kuhn and T. K. Sham, Phys. Rev. B
49
, 1647â
1661
(1994).
https://doi.org/10.1103/physrevb.49.1647
in case of RA-AuCu, a negative peak shift of Cu2p
3/2
by â¼0.30 eV occurred, and this might be attributed to electroneutrality for maintaining the AuCu alloy structure. These blue and red shifts observed in Au4f and Cu2p binding energies are in agreement with the previous literature
30â32
30. W. Eberhardt, S. C. Wu, R. Garrett, D. Sondericker, and F. Jona, Phys. Rev. B
31
, 8285â
8287
(1985).
https://doi.org/10.1103/physrevb.31.8285
31. M. Kuhn and T. K. Sham, Phys. Rev. B
49
, 1647â
1661
(1994).
https://doi.org/10.1103/physrevb.49.1647
32. M. Yoshitake and K. Yoshihara, Surf. Interface Anal.
17
, 711â
718
(1991).
https://doi.org/10.1002/sia.740171005
and, thus, verify the formation of AuCu alloys by the modified RA treatment. Note that all hydroxides were reduced to Au and AuCu metallic states after the RA treatment [
Fig. 2(c)
].

FIG. 2.
X-ray photoelectron spectroscopy (XPS) profiles of (a) Au4f, (b) Cu2p, and (c) O1s for the RA-AuCu and RA-Au (w/o Cu) nanostructure, respectively. The XPS profile for the bare Au film is included for comparison.

Figure 3
shows high-angle annular dark-field scanning transmission electron microscopy (HAADF-STEM) images [
Fig. 3(a)
] and STEM-EDS maps of RA-AuCu [
Figs. 3(b)â3(d)
]. TEM analysis reveals that Cu (â¼3.0 at. %) is uniformly distributed in RA-AuCu, as shown in
Fig. 3(d)
and Table S1 of the
supplementary material
. Note that Cu contents in the RA-AuCu alloy can be varied by controlling the deposition amount of Cu on Au thin films before the RA treatment. For instance, increasing Cu electrodeposition time from 10 s to 60 s leads to about an absolute 8% increase in Cu contents in RA-AuCu, whereas a thin layer of Cu formed by underpotential deposition (UPD) of Cu on Au contains only 1.6% of Cu in RA-AuCu alloy (see Fig. S4 and Table S1 of the
supplementary material
).

FIG. 3.
(a) High-angle annular dark-field scanning transmission electron microscopy (HAADF-STEM) image of RA-AuCu alloy nanostructures. STEM-EDS maps for (b) Au, (c) Cu, and (d) Au and Cu, respectively.

CO
2
RR performance of nanostructured Au and AuCu alloy was evaluated in a single compartment cell under a three-electrode configuration in a CO
2
-saturated 0.2 M KHCO
3
electrolyte (pH 6.8). It should be noted that the KHCO
3
electrolyte was pre-electrolyzed for 10 h to minimize impurities in the electrolyte before all electrochemical CO
2
reduction tests were carried out (see the section titled âExperimental methodsâ in the
supplementary material
). Linear sweep voltammogram (LSV) in
Fig. 4(a)
shows higher electrochemical current density for nanostructured RA-Au and RA-AuCu than that for a bare Au film in all potentials. Note that all current density is normalized by a geometric area of a working electrode. We then carried gas chromatography to measure gas products evolved during electrolysis. Only H
2
and CO were detected from the gas measurement. Note that FE for H
2
and CO is mostly calculated to be about 95%â105% in total, indicating that H
2
and CO are only major products. Similar to the LSV result, nanostructured Au and AuCu exhibit much higher CO FE than bare Au [see
Fig. 4(b)
and Table S2 of the
supplementary material
). For instance, RA-Au and RA-AuCu show almost the same CO FE of â¼95% at â0.49 V, whereas the CO FE of a bare Au film is 59%. Compared to the bare Au film, the dramatic increase in the CO FE in the RA-Au and RA-AuCu electrodes originates from (1) the increased electrochemical active sites and (2) the modified local environment (e.g., local pH) in nanostructures during CO
2
electrolysis.
9
9. J. Kim, J. T. Song, H. Ryoo, J.-G. Kim, S.-Y. Chung, and J. Oh, J. Mater. Chem. A
6
, 5119â
5128
(2018).
https://doi.org/10.1039/c8ta01010b
Note that RA-AuCu nanoalloy exhibits a slightly enhanced selective CO production over RA-Au in potential regions >â0.49 V. We also investigated the effect of Cu concentration in the AuCu alloy nanostructures on CO
2
RR activity (see Fig. S5 and Table S2 of the
supplementary material
): small incorporation of Cu (<10%) into RA-AuCu seems to enhance the selective reduction of CO
2
to CO at a low overpotential.

FIG. 4.
The comparisons of electrochemical CO
2
reduction properties for bare Au thin film, RA-Au w/o Cu, and RA-AuCu in a CO
2
-saturated 0.2 M KHCO
3
electrolyte (pH 6.8). (a) The results for the linear sweep voltammetry (LSV) measurement. (b) Applied potential-dependent CO Faradaic efficiency plots. (c) Time-dependent CO Faradaic efficiency during CO
2
electrolysis at an applied potential of â0.49 V.

Cu alloying in Au nanostructures also improves the stability of CO
2
RR activity in prolonged electrolysis time.
Figure 4(c)
shows the time evolution of CO FE of RA-Au, RA-AuCu, and bare Au electrodes at an applied potential of â0.49 V. The detail of CO FE values is described in Tables S3 and S4 of the
supplementary material
. As shown in
Fig. 4(c)
, both the nanostructured RA-Au and RA-AuCu electrocatalysts show highly durable and selective CO
2
RR, whereas a bare Au film suffers from dramatic degradation of CO FE from 50% to 16% in 3 h of CO
2
electrolysis. The rapid deactivation of the bare Au film is attributed, mainly, for blocking or poisoning of active sites by metal impurities and/or chemical species.
33,34
33. A. Wuttig and Y. Surendranath, ACS Catal.
5
, 4479â
4484
(2015).
https://doi.org/10.1021/acscatal.5b00808
34. H. Kim, H. S. Jeon, M. S. Jee, E. B. Nursanto, J. P. Singh, K. Chae, Y. J. Hwang, and B. K. Min, ChemSusChem
9
, 2097â
2102
(2016).
https://doi.org/10.1002/cssc.201600228
More importantly, the stability of RA-AuCu is significantly improved as compared to RA-Au (w/o Cu). Dilute AuCu nanoalloy sustains CO FE over 90% for 5 h, whereas the CO FE of nanostructured Au without Cu drops to below 70%. Strikingly, the CO FE of RA-AuCu remains over 80% for 12 h. In fact, the enhanced stability of nanostructured AuCu alloy can be seen in various Cu compositions (see Fig. S6 of the
supplementary material
).

Recently, Wuttig
et al.
reported that the presence of trace metal ion impurities such as Cu, Ag, and Au in the electrolyte could be deposited on surfaces and poison catalysts during the electrolysis process.
33
33. A. Wuttig and Y. Surendranath, ACS Catal.
5
, 4479â
4484
(2015).
https://doi.org/10.1021/acscatal.5b00808
Indeed, XPS of both RA-Au and RA-AuCu after CO
2
reduction for 12 h revealed that the surface concentration of Cu increased from 0% to 12% for RA-Au and from 10% to 18% for RA-AuCu (see Fig. S7 of the
supplementary material
). Closer investigation at the Cu2p spectra (931.8 eV) indicates that metallic Cu is deposited on the catalystsâ surface during electrolysis. Note that no contents other than Au and Cu were detected after CO
2
RR (see Fig. S8 of the
supplementary material
). This surface metallic Cu originates from trace impurities in KHCO
3
salts as confirmed via inductively coupled plasma mass spectrometry (ICP-MS) (see Table S5 of the
supplementary material
). Thus, metallic Cu deposits on Au surfaces decrease catalytic activity for CO
2
RR by obstructing active sites (e.g., grain boundaries) for CO
2
RR.
33,35,36
33. A. Wuttig and Y. Surendranath, ACS Catal.
5
, 4479â
4484
(2015).
https://doi.org/10.1021/acscatal.5b00808
35. X. Feng, K. Jiang, S. Fan, and M. W. Kanan, J. Am. Chem. Soc.
137
, 4606â
4609
(2015).
https://doi.org/10.1021/ja5130513
36. R. G. Mariano, K. McKelvey, H. S. White, and M. W. Kanan, Science
358
, 1187 (2017).
https://doi.org/10.1126/science.aao3691
It is interesting to note that dilute Cu alloying in Au is effective for sustaining CO
2
-to-CO conversion activity despite trace Cu deposition on the RA-AuCu surface although the mechanism for this enhancement is unclear. Further study will be required to unravel the role of alloying on the degradation mechanisms in CO
2
RR.

Next, inspired from the RA treatment on Cu/Au thin films, we demonstrate an
in situ
tailoring process to re-activate the poisoned nanostructured Au catalysts for durable CO
2
RR. The process is established by repeating our RA treatment (sequential anodization and reduction) on Cu-poisoned RA-Au after the CO
2
electrolysis test.
Figures 5(a)â5(d)
describe the details of the process with characteristic morphologies at each repeating step. Note that each sample is denoted as RA-Au-the number of applied RA treatment (e.g., RA-Au-1, 2, and 3). We started the CO
2
RR stability examination with RA-Au-1 that was fabricated under the identical RA treatment condition of the RA-Au w/o Cu sample (i.e., anodization at 2.5 V for 40 min and reduction at â0.5 mA cm
â2
). The first RA treatment produced the porous Au nanostructures with the total height of about 200 nm, which includes the 40 nm-thick bottom Au layer (i.e., an unreacted Au thin film layer). The morphology of RA-Au-1 [the same as RA-Au (w/o Cu)] appears to be almost similar to that of RA-AuCu, although the total thickness of the RA-Au-1 is slightly thin. As shown in
Fig. 5(e)
and Table S6 of the
supplementary material
, the CO FE for RA-Au-1 drops to nearly 70% with a declined current density in 3.5 h. We then re-applied RA treatment on the degraded RA-Au-1 sample (on which metallic Cu is deposited from the electrolyte) to form RA-Au-2. As clearly shown in
Fig. 5(e)
, RA-Au-2 exhibits revived CO
2
RR activity with 94% CO FE at 5.5 h. Furthermore, current density during the initial minute of the CO
2
RR test for each sample also increases from â1.4 mA cm
â2
for RA-Au-1 to â1.8 mA cm
â2
for RA-Au-2, in part, due to the enhanced surface area, as can be estimated from SEM images of
Figs. 5(a)â5(d)
. The height grows from 160 nm at RA-Au-1 to 235 nm at RA-Au-2. We also confirmed from electrochemical surface area (ECSA) measurement that roughness factors linearly increase from 8.7 to 21.3 with repeating RA treatment times (see Fig. S9 of the
supplementary material
). More surprisingly, catalystâs lifespan for keeping CO FE over 70% is increased with additional RA treatments: RA-Au-3 lasts â¼6 h, while RA-Au-1 lasts for only 3.5 h. Note that the increased surface area of RA-Au-3 from the repeated RA treatment is not responsible for the improved durability of the catalysts. For instance, RA-Au samples with a similar morphology to RA-Au-3, prepared by repeating the RA treatments three times (RA-Au-3-straight) without incorporating CO
2
reduction between the RA treatments, do not show apparent improvement in stability: CO selectivity, which is defined by CO FE/total FE, declines in 3.5 h for RA-Au-3-straight declines to â¼70% in 4 h, which is similar to that for RA-Au-1 (see Figs. S10 and S11 and Table S7 of the
supplementary material
). The enhanced stability of re-activated RA-Au is believed to come from dilute Cu alloying in RA-Au-3 (â¼2 wt. % Cu) since RA-Au-3-straight does not contain Cu, as revealed by XPS (see Fig. S12 of the
supplementary material
), HAADF-STEM, and STEM-EDS mapping characterization (see Figs. S13 and S14 of the
supplementary material
). When we finished CO
2
RR tests for both samples, the atomic Cu/Au ratio further increased to 4.63 at. % and 2.3 at. % for RA-Au-3 and RA-Au-3-straight, respectively (see Fig. S15 of the
supplementary material
).

FIG. 5.
The evaluation of Au catalysts synthesized via electrochemical technique repeating reduced anodic (RA) treatment [anodization (anod.) and reduction (red.)] followed by a CO
2
reduction reaction (CO
2
RR). [(a)â(d)] SEM images for the morphological change in Au nanostructures. (e) Stability test results for the firstly synthesized Au nanostructure via RA treatment on bare Au thin film (RA-Au-1), re-RA treated RA-Au-1 after CO
2
RR (RA-Au-2), and re-RA treated RA-Au-2 after CO
2
RR (RA-Au-3). CO
2
electrolysis was carried out at â0.49 V.
III. CONCLUSION
Section:

Dilute AuCu alloy nanostructures containing â¼3% of Cu composition were created by the electrochemical treatment process consisting of Cu deposition, anodization, and reduction in a 0.2 M KHCO
3
aqueous solution on a 200 nm-thick Au thin film. CO
2
RR performance on a dilute AuCu alloy catalyst is significantly enhanced as compared to pure Au nanostructures, exhibiting 95% CO FE at â0.49 V. In addition, a dilute AuCu nanostructure maintains CO FE over 80% for 12 h, while a pure Au nanostructured sample suffers quick degradation within 4.5 h. Notably, for the case of pure Au nanostructures, it was found that Cu impurity from the KHCO
3
electrolyte is readily deposited during CO
2
electrolysis, which is considered as the main cause of the rapid degradation. Hence, the formation of a dilute AuCu alloy catalyst is revealed to be a key strategy for improving the durability for CO
2
electrolysis. Finally, based on this phenomenon, we demonstrated an
in situ
electrochemical technique repeating the anodization and reduction process on used Au nanostructures for reactivation of catalytic performance. By re-applying the electrochemical treatment process after a long-term CO
2
electrolysis test on the Au nanostructure, deactivated Au nanostructures are completely revived, even with a prolonged lifetime, due to dilute AuCu alloy formation by Cu impurities from the electrolyte. Thus, our electrochemical process provides a facile method to form nanostructured alloy catalysts for higher CO
2
RR activity and can be a promising strategy for recycling deactivated catalysts.
SUPPLEMENTARY MATERIAL
Section:

supplementary-material.div:
Experimental procedures and catalyst characterization are described in detail. Spectroscopy data (XPS) and structural images (SEM and TEM) for additional samples are arranged in the
supplementary material
. Additional electrochemical evaluation data of CO
2
reduction are included.

div.div: AUTHORSâ CONTRIBUTION
Section:
J.K. and J.T.S. contributed equally to this work.
DATA AVAILABILITY
Section:

The data that support the findings of this study are available within the article and its
supplementary material
.

This work was financially supported by the Korea CCS R&D Center (KCRC) grant funded by the Korean government (Ministry of Science, ICT, and Future Planning) (Grant No. NRF-2014M1A&A1049303) and the National Research Foundation of Korea (Grant No. NRF-2019M1A2A2065612).
